I’ve spent almost two weeks reviewing recent surveys on attitudes toward energy and climate change. During that time I’ve lambasted the climate movement for its poorly thought out messaging strategy.
Not to be thought of as someone who simply acts as a critic, today it’s time to offer an alternative strategy. Here are five recommendations to create a more effective climate change communication strategy.
Tomorrow I’ll offer up recommendations six through 10.
I welcome alternative opinions. Let’s start a dialogue.
#climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal #severeweather #climateaction #emissions #carbonemissions #climatescience

Tony- I think these are great strategies, and I look forward to 6-10. Sometimes, I think of the climate situation a little more like a byproduct of our relatively immature energy system. We're still only separated by a handful of generations from when electric transmission was even developed! We've taken societal shortcuts to handle the rapid deployment of electrical usage, and one of the downsides of those shortcuts is that we've rapidly increased the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. We've also pumped vast amounts of other extremely harmful substances into the atmosphere, which have had enormous and almost incalculable health effects on the global population.
So- while we do indeed have a climate situation on our hands, it is going to be hard to get society on board with trying to come up with the best solution when we take the divisive approach. We need to take a holistic approach to solving the energy situation, not just the climate situation.
Tom - couldn't agree more. I have made the same "holistic approach" point a number of times. And hopefully, in the not too distant future we can take politics out of the equation - at least to some extent - and make it about the facts.
Seems to me the objective should be to focus on reasonably priced energy. The nature of green energy will lead to lower CO2 emissions levels. Aim for what is achievable, as opposed to the unrealistic.
For the most part that is what is occurring. Despite their inherent drawbacks solar and wind are proliferating because they have reached price parity with oil and gas - sort of. In terms of other technologies, getting price points down requires research, investments, and time. Not too mention economies of scale - which is a bit of a chicken-egg dilemma. Bottom line - we don't know which technologies will yield the best price performance until we flesh them out.
